byline.contributor: Omar al-Jawoshy reported from Baghdad, and Tim Arango from Istanbul. An employee of The New York Times contributed reporting from Salahuddin Province, Iraq.
byline.original: By OMAR AL-JAWOSHY and TIM ARANGO

abstract: Iraq's Shiite-dominated government faces challenge in stabilizing wartorn city of Tikrit after retaking it from Islamic State forces; displaced Sunni families begin to return to area and Shiite militias provide security in sign of easing sectarian tensions.
lead_paragraph: The Islamic State was driven from Tikrit, the hometown of Saddam Hussein and the largest city the terrorist group has lost in either Iraq or Syria.

headline.main: Iraqi Families Return to Fragile Stability in Tikrit After Liberation From ISIS
headline.print_headline: Liberated From ISIS, Tikrit Poses a Challenge

snippet: The Islamic State was driven from Tikrit, the hometown of Saddam Hussein and the largest city the terrorist group has lost in either Iraq or Syria.

keywords.value: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
keywords.name: organizations
